Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: The Internet under Widespread Shelter-in-Place: Resilience, Response, and Lessons for the Future

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The spread of COVID-19 has led to unprecedented and ongoing changes to daily life, including shelter-in-place orders, widespread closing of businesses and schools, and work-from-home and school-from-home at previously unknown levels. These changes in behavior are placing extraordinary demands on the Internet. This project will measure the Internet’s ability to meet these demands, including comparing its performance before, during, and after the peak of COVID-19; whether the amount of change varies between areas heavily impacted by COVID-19 and those less impacted; and whether and how large networks adapt.

To provide this rich understanding, this project will combine multiple Internet-scale datasets that provide complementary views to investigate how responses to COVID-19 have impacted the Internet and how networks have reacted. Specifically, the project will measure how workloads have changed and their impact on networks in response to COVID-19 by measuring traffic patterns worldwide and the impact of congestion on performance globally. In addition, the project will measure how networks react to these changes in workloads by monitoring path changes that indicate rerouting of traffic during surges induced by measures in response to COVID-19, identifying whether traffic management is deployed for (de)prioritizing certain network flows, and measuring whether networks add interconnections and upgrade capacity.

Measuring the network impact of COVID-19 will illuminate the Internet’s strengths and weak points and is a crucial step towards improving the Internet’s future resilience in the face of pandemics, natural disasters, large scale conflict, and terrorist attacks. The Internet is designed for resiliency, but large cloud and content providers have been avoiding public Internet exchange points and the public Internet in favor of private interconnection and private wide-area networks. This project will understand the impact of these decisions. The relative performance of these strategies under stress should play a critical role in informing future research, funding, and design of critical Internet infrastructure.

All of the data, measurement tools, and analysis code used for this study will be published to the greatest extent permitted by our affiliated organizations and prevailing data privacy regulations, with links to these artifacts posted at
https://covid19-internet-resilience.github.io/. The goal is to keep these artifacts publicly available in perpetuity via free storage and cloud repositories, though the duration is subject to the availability of such resources. The tools and code will be maintained for as long as they remain useful for measuring Internet resilience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Internet plays a critical role in supporting society during the COVID-19 pandemic, but it has been challenged. The spread of COVID-19 led to unprecedented changes to daily life, including shelter-in-place orders, widespread closing of businesses and schools, necessitating working and schooling from home. These changes created a perfect storm of stressors on the Internet, especially on routes between residential networks and teleconferencing, remote desktop, cloud, and similar services. 

 

Outbreaks increase prevalence of working from home, using applications that demand low latency and high bandwidth from residential networks that typically do not see high volumes of such traffic. Children and furloughed workers were also at home during the workday, using remote schooling, streaming video, and gaming applications that are traditionally used in the evening. Networks provision capacity based on historical trends and estimated growth, since traffic is typically predictable and periodic. This unprecedented situation upended trends, potentially straining existing capacity, and outpacing networks' abilities to provision.

 

Our project findings so far covered topics about how the Internet performed and adapted under this abrupt shift. First, we studied how usage changed. Looking at the early phases of the pandemic, there was increased demand on certain Internet services (video streaming, videoconferencing) and in certain types of networks (residential ones), but latency did not seem to be affected in residential networks. Tier-1 networks saw reduced usage and slightly higher average latency, possibly due to congestion. Mobile networks saw mixed changes in usage.

 

Second, we tested whether networks adapted to changing demands from subscribers by using traffic differentiation to limit bandwidth consumption. We fortunately found no evidence of changes in policies: throttling in the US that has been observed for several years (video streaming) remained in place, and we did not find any evidence of throttling of applications seeing increased usage during the pandemic (videoconferencing). There was some evidence of port-based differentiation in a French ISP, but it was likely due to a security appliance (as opposed to a policy to slow down legitimate traffic). We believe two factors account for these observations: most networks either had or added capacity to handle changes in load without needing to throttle, and content providers adjusted bandwidth usage to reduce overloading networks to ensure that clients achieved good performance. 

 

While the one-year duration of this project ended, the pandemic is expected to extend for much longer globally and the fallout on availability of network capacity to meet demand for a remote workforce needs continued study. Our initial findings indicate that the Internet weathered the storm quite well on average; however, much work remains to be done to identify networks that fared particularly well or poorly, understand why such discrepancies exist, and provide guidance on how to best adapt the Internet to ensure no one is left behind if and when the next pandemic arises.
